The conformational ensembles were built in the RPBS Web Portal (https://mobyle.rpbs.univ-paris-diderot.fr/cgi-bin/portal.py#forms::Frog2) using the FRee Online druG conformation generation (Frog2). Quamtum mechanics computations were run on the Consorci de Serveis Universitaris de Catalunya (CSUC).

column2: we have used the Frog 2.14 software to explore the conformational preferences of all microstates for the Sampl7 molecules. The molecular geometries of the compounds were fully optimized at the B3LYP/6-31G(d) level of theory
column3: taking into account the solvation effect of water on the geometrical parameters of the solutes
column4: using the IEFPCM version of the MST

column1: model. The resulting minima were verified by vibrational frequency analysis
column2: which gave positive frequencies in all cases. Then
column3: the relative energies of the whole set of conformational species were refined from single-point computations performed at the MP2/aug-cc-pVDZ levels of theory. In addition
column4: the gas phase estimate of the free energy difference for all microstates was derived by combining the MP2 enegies with zero point energy corrections (ZPE). Finally
column5: solvation effects were added by using the B3LYP/6-31G(d) version of the IEFPCM/MST model
column6: which is a quantum mechanical (QM) self-consistent continuum solvation method.

column1: The pKa was determined using both
column2: the experimental hydration free energy of the proton (-270.28 kcal/mol) and a Boltzmann’s weighting scheme to the relative stabilities of the conformational species determined for the microstates involved in the equilibrium constant for the dissociation reaction following the thermodynamic cycle reported in previous studies [Brown TN
column3: Mora Diez N. Computational determination of aqueous (pKa) values of protonated benzimidazoles (part 1). J. Phys. Chem. B. 110(18)
column4: 9270–9279 (2006)]. The uncertainties of our method is reported according our previous work Pérez-Areales FJ
column18: synthesis and multitarget biological profiling of second-generation anti-Alzheimer rhein-huprine hybrids. Future Med Chem. 2017 Jun;9(10):965-981. doi: 10.4155/fmc-2017-0049]
